Reviews.Content: Utter Hell!!! Students mostly live here and it is obvious that once you've signed your contract the staff couldn't give a f**k. When I first arrived I wasn't shown around and when I had finally found my room it was utterly filthy! I really mean disgusting! I just can't explain the dissapointment I felt. There were cockroaches on the wall, I remember writing my name in the dust and the toilet had not been flushed (I am not kidding). I just dumped my luggage and cried. The walls desperatly need painting. The carpets need to be changed. All the hallways are filthy and never vacuumed. The bin areas on each level are completley unacceptable. Here bags of rubblish becomed piled high 2meters! Flies! The stench wafts through the building. I will not use the kitchens. I simply can't go through that. After a year of being here a year, I now have a diagnosed skin condition because of where I live. Treatment costs a lot. I am someone who used to go bush hiking for a month at a time and still be healthy!Over the couse of the year my mail and others', has been mysteriously stollen periodically. The staff never bothered to contact us to tell us of the problem. It was not untill the police were called in that they were made to.Every 2 or 3 weeks I since the beginning of the year I have received threatening letters telling me I will be denied access to the building if I don't pay my rent. However, as my account is set up automatically the money was ALWAYS there! They never apologised for this treatment nor endevoured to stop the letters to this day! This is NOT how you treat a paying client.I am a Sydney University student and went to my student union. They have told me how dreadfully sydney students have been treated there. Please contact them if you are wanting advice on where to look for student accomodation. I want to warn all overseas students that you WILL be taken advantage of. Prices will be raised for you guys. Make sure you speak english well. That American and Asian students are particularly conned in because of overseas contractual aggreements.This is NOT a friendly or truthfull place. The staff are down right arrogant and rude simply because they already have your money. There are no social events apart from one pathetic BBQ a year. The gym that they had advertised was a brocken arm press and a bike with no seat. The pool is filthy.The owners, management and staff of this business display no sense of professional pride in their work and product.I have read the other reviews and want to clear up that the people who had an ok experience were not students but short-term visitors who were given rooms that are cleaned daily.I have been coping by getting a (private) professional cleaner in to completley clean my room after moving in and then did what ever it took not to be at home too long or to avoid staff. However, the noise in this building is so loud but luckily I could escape to my nearby library to study. During my exams they demanded that I move rooms because my room had been privately sold!!! So much for supporting the student who is also paying their wages.To anyone looking to move here I hope your experience is a better. I feel that by writing this review hopefully, someoe will listen.
Reviews.Author: unhappystudent

Reviews.Content: Ok if you're a student, but be careful I stayed here for a semester as an international student, and I have a couple pieces of advice for others staying at the Unilodge long-term. This is going to be a fairly long/detailed review, so it may only be worth reading if you're in such a position.First of all (and I realize this is not the Unilodge's fault), do NOT walk alone at night, especially in Victoria Park (across the street in front of the University of Sydney). The park is gorgeous by day, but my friend and I were mugged at needlepoint there one night, and were later advised by campus security to only travel in groups after dark, even if it was shortly after sunset. Take a taxi door-to-door if you have the money; since I usually didn't, I became very familiar with Sydney's great bus system. If you're out so late that the buses aren't running, seriously, either crash with a friend or take advantage of the University's (free) campus security escort service. Just be extra polite to the drivers - they have to ferry a lot of drunk students around, and as nice and patient as they are, I'm sure that must get old fast.Secondly, if you open an account with an Australian bank, do NOT, under any circumstances, have your ATM card or other sensitive information sent to the Unilodge - just pick it up at the branch instead. I was just one of many students who had their ATM card and PIN number stolen, and I immediately lost all but $3 of the money in my account as a result (this was about two weeks after arriving). The Unilodge employees were less than helpful, even going so far as to suggest that perhaps my best friend/roommate (supposedly the only other person with access to our room's mailbox) had stolen it. After speaking to several employees, I was told that the only thing they could do was replace the lock on my mailbox, as there was no security camera in the mail room. I fail to see how this was supposed to solve the problem, since the thief clearly had easy access to all the students' secure mailboxes, and I was frankly appalled at the staff's overall blase attitude towards the theft of all but $3 of a foreign student's money - a situation that could have been disastrous if not for an emergency credit card and the good graces of Westpac, who let me continue to withdraw money on credit even before it was actually restored to my account.Unlike the Unilodge staff, the Westpac bank employees across the street were extremely sensitive and helpful; one man, who had been working there for a while, explained that they usually tell students to pick up their ATM cards and PINs at the branch, since apparently this problem has been going on at the Unilodge for quite some time.On to the room.Let me be clear on this, since we weren't aware until we walked into the apartment: if you're sharing with another student, you will have your own bed, but NOT your own room - it's freshman year all over again. It's very difficult to get privacy of any kind in a Unilodge apartment - in our room, even the saloon-style bathroom doors wouldn't close completely - so we got by by moving one of the beds down from the loft and rigging up walls with sheets and twine. It wasn't too terrible because I was living with my best friend, but I shudder to think what it would've been like with someone whose company I didn't enjoy.Some of the other students in our program had a balcony off of their room; we, however, had one window, which opened onto a roofed indoor courtyard. For this reason, our room had little to no natural light or fresh air, and even when the weather finally cooled down in the autumn, the room improved from pretty much unbearable to merely stuffy. Living without air conditioning in Sydney's warm season is a little rough in any case, but doing it in a room with no other kind of ventilation was brutal. Although some other students had full fridges, our room only had a mini-fridge, which was definitely not a sufficient size for two people with no meal plan. I'm still trying to understand why every student paid the same for one semester's accommodation when some rooms were much better equipped than others, but whatever.The walls were thin enough that we pretty much knew what was going on in all the adjacent rooms, and the indoor courtyard echoed and amplified the noise from every other room with a window facing it. It's not too bad if you've got headphones or earplugs, and I was grateful for the eye mask I'd brought - I couldn't close the windows to cut down on the noise, or the curtains to cut down on the other apartments' lights, as that would have also cut off the closest thing to fresh, moving air.The rooms don't have much for furniture; we quickly realized that although we each had a desk, there was no way to store schoolbooks or anything like that, aside from stacking them on the tables. Being cheap foreign students, we constructed shelves out of milk crates.There are common lounges/kitchens on each floor, but don't expect much. The cheap couches were without cushions about half the time (I don't know if other students were taking them, or what), and don't expect to be able to cook anything that can't be made on a stove top or in your room's microwave. The Unilodge is conveniently located for a University student, and it was nice to have a small pool  hot tub in the basement, but if you're given the choice, definitely opt to stay at one of the other student accommodations. The Sydney University Village was especially nice - everyone gets their own room, the apartments there are equipped with full kitchens, and there are plenty of windows to get you through the Sydney heat.Basically, the room was bearable for a semester-long stay, but it actually made me homesick for my own college's dorms. Not so bad if you're a student, but if I were past my college years, I would probably be wary of staying in a place that's mainly used for student housing.
Reviews.Author: bilby86

Reviews.Content: leslie from CO We were at the Unilodge for 2 days. Got there early in AM and were able to keep our suitcases in a locked room while we hopped on a nearby bus for Sydney Harbor. All staff were helpful. We were put on the 4th floor interior so less noise. We had a twin bed room. There was a microwave, small fridge, sink and even a tea set up and cookies. Bathroom was adequate. We felt this was a great room for the price--$102/night--I was rather nervous that it was so inexpensive as I had heard the rooms in Sydney could go for $300+. Lots of ethnic restaurants nearby. We walked to the Powerhouse Museum--a real gem. Had no experience with exercise room or any of the other problem places the student had written about. Had breakfast in the small restaurant in the lobby which was $10 US for 2 bagels and 2 coffees--rather high. Went somewhere else the next morning.
Reviews.Author: lesliesuej

Reviews.Content: Horrendous - not a good word to say about it! I have read the comments below and have to say I agree entirely with those who have rated this place badly.I have actually stayed here for a year as a student in the apartments, and it is the most overpriced ($345AUD A WEEK FOR A TINY ROOM) and ghastly accommodation I've ever had the misfortune to stay in.I moved in in July last year, and when I got here (after a 28 hour journey) a contract was thrust under my nose, and I was told to sign by the next morning. I was given no tour/guidance as to where anything was (i.e. kitchen etc) and the staff were rude and arrogant. The contract I signed had an inflated price than that which I had been quoted, but left as an international student from Scotland, with no where else to go and with no family and friends in Sydney I decided to sign.I should have cut and run!Over the course of the last year the facilities, which were advertised when I moved in, have decreased and broken. For example, the mini-gym (which was mostly broken and minimal to start with) has been removed, the buisness centre (the only place to print in a so called student accommodation, where work must be done) has gone and the student lounges which are advertised as social have 2 old, smelly couches, a TV and a vending machine (which Unilodge will not take responsibility for) in each and are always empty.The place is awful, the rooms are tiny and the kitchens are constantly dirty. The only oven in the four floor building (with over 400 student bedrooms) looks as though it has never been cleaned - it is caked in layers of spilt food. It is also the worst oven Ive ever used - it burns the bottom of items and does not cook the middle!The expensive laundry facilities are often out of order.The social events which are advertised on the unilodge website do not happen at UniLodge Sydney. In the time I have been here there has been one organised BBQ.The loction is good for uni and there is a shopping centre for groceries near by - the only good points!The staff turn-over says alot about this hotel - they are unable to keep most staff for more than one month. Those who do stay rarely speak good English. There is only one staff member, to my knowledge, that is efficient at her job. If you do have the misfortune to stay here then hope you get her to check you in, otherwise you may find you do not get the price or room which you booked.The games room consists of one, broken table tennis table and the bar and grill is literaly a counter top with a sink - no cooking facilities for the grill and no bar at all!!!As far as I can find there is no complaints procedure, and the staff continue to be obnoxious and unhelpful. In some cases they are down right rude.All in all, don't stay here if you want a pleasant, friendly or value for money experince. I hope no-one has to endure the experience that I have.
Reviews.Author: binza87

Reviews.Content: Noisey, definitely student accomodation Unilodge is in a great location, right next to Gleb so that was fantastic. Next to many cafes and restaurants, however the place itself had much to be desired for. The rooms were noisey. You could hear the bathroom all night and the aircon from above. Being on the top floor really had no advantages. The rooms are definitely designed for student living. The bathrooms need renovation, old and off colour. The staff though on the other hand were very pleasant and friendly. Very helpful. If you're on a budget then this maybe the hotel to go for - personally I think there are better ones in Sydney.
Reviews.Author: Kxi

Reviews.Content: unfriendly, run-down, noisy i unfortunaltely had to stay there for some weeks (it was booked and pre-arranged and no change was possible). to sum up: i don't recommend this hotel to anyone. stuff is unfriendly, rooms and furnishings are run-down and it's noisy. if you have the choice: don't stay there! some positive issues concerning the location: just accross the street there is a big shopping center, this may be very helpful for people need to stay for a longer time and the bus stop is in front of the building, all busses departing from there are driving straight to the city center or circular quay this is rather comfortable.
Reviews.Author: Ray_Stuttgart

Reviews.Content: Great For A Budget! I honestly can't figure out why so many people gave this hotel such rotten reviews; my friend and I stayed at the Unilodge from 5/11-5/18 and we couldn't have more positive things to say about the property and the staff! Everyone was extremely friendly and helpful, when we originally booked our room, they only had a single queen bed room available, but when we checked in, they found us a room with two twins and a bathroom ensuite! The location isn't that far from Darling Harbour (a good 20 minute walk), taxi fare is only around $10 AUD (and there's ALWAYS taxis nearby the hotel!), there's plenty of restaurants around to grab a bite to eat, and the mall is right across the street! As for our room, it's small, but large enough for two people to not get in each other's way. Our housekeeper gave us fresh towels and soap everyday, and I could swear that they also changed our linens everyday as well. I can't say enough about how great this hotel was, I'll definitely be staying there again the next time I'm in Australia!
Reviews.Author: hawaiishoegirlie

Reviews.Content: Modest but clean facilties near downtown for budget travellers
Reviews.Author: zenban

Reviews.Content: Big dissappointment OK if you knew you were staying budget then maybe you'd expect what you get but this place is billed as three star by AirmIles UK. We never sussed the Unilodge name.The room was tiny, bordering an atrium and every noise was just amplified. We would expect this of a University halls of residence but we thought we were in a decent hotel! Not the place to sleep off jetlag for a couple of Brits.The door to the bathroom was a louvred swing type. Think Western saloon type crossed with the worst 70's bedroom cupboard style and you'll be getting the idea. No way of locking it and EVERY sound goes straight through.The swimming pool and gym are small and a very long walk from reception through the depths of the basement, consequently little used. Also completely unattended.
Reviews.Author: IanJudge

Reviews.Content: Must try harder Stayed for 2 nights at the end January 2007.First problem was that room had 2 single beds and when we contacted front desk they advised that hotel was full - offered complimentary car parking ($10) as token gesture.There are lots of students barbequing and running around but we didn't find this to be a problem.Room was not serviced after the first night. When I raised this with the front reception they said that because we did not put out the PLEASE SERVICE ROOM sign they don't service because of privacy/security constraints. I said that it would have been nice to have been told this rule when checking in. No compensation/sorry was offered.Checked out after 2 nights and was asked to pay for parking but said that this was free due to room type being single beds. Was then asked who told me this. I described the person and car parking was given for free.I would only recommend this hotel for very independent travellers who are not fussed by surroundings and a 10/15 minute walk into the city. The hotel is opposite a supermarket complex and there is a microwave in room.
Reviews.Author: GoodGuest

Reviews.Content: too far!!! Well this hotel was actually good but be prepared for a decent hike to the centre of town or a willingness to spend large amounts on public transport. The location is the only problem with this place.
Reviews.Author: geordiemma

Reviews.Content: Got to agree with previous reviews This hotel is some sort of student halls of residence, the name UNIlodge sort of gives it away. That isn't a problem in itself but it is a bit gauling to be paying a resonable amount to stay in a student room, albeit serviced every day with coffee / towels etc. The rooms are not well presented adding to the low rent feel of the place. Unlike previous reviewers we didn't have a problem with the staff and the location was OK (easy busses to the city). Can't say I recomend it unless the rate was a lot cheaper to compete with a hostel.
Reviews.Author: AlVic

Reviews.Content: Absolutely the worst We arrived in the early evening and everything appeared to be in order during check-in. We should have heeded the manager tossing the pen and registration form at us as a warning.Arrived at the 4th and a half floor with all of our luggage, opened the rooms and found two single beds and one of the tiniest rooms ever. We decided that this just wouldn't do for our honeymoon. We called the front desk and they said changing rooms wouldn't be a problem but it was. We had used our Gold Crown points and booked this hotel as it was the only one that would honor the program.My wife went down to get the room keys and 45 minutes later I became worried and went down to determine what what causing the delay. This forced me to leave some of my baggage in the hallway unattended.I arrived in the lobby to find her in the business center trying to find the so-called voucher. She was forced to pay a $20 internet useage fee as the staff and management were unwilling to assist in clearing up the problem.Furthermore, the manager was insiting we leave a credit card number in case they did not recieve payment from the Gold Crown program. When I explained we did not plan on leaving a credit card as it was their internal problem, the manager became confrontational and said I had insulted the way the staff was dressed. I asked the staff member if anything I said offended her and she said no. Following this, the manager stormed of and refused to deal with us any longer. There is no hospitality in hospitality management at this hotel.The rooms feel like I imagine a prison cell would feel like. It seems as if this is temporary housing or something for college kids which normally wouldn't be a problem but there was a disproportionate number that were rude and immature. It was noisy and poorly laid out. Steer clear of this hotel if at all possible.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Rudest Staff Ever!!!!!! Enough To Put You Off Seriously, I don't think I have ever encountered such arrogant staff. The place is nothing special at all, no one to help you with the luggage, rooms are tiny (below average) and facing and internal courtyard (barely any natural light...felt like being in a cell). Airconditioning barely worked and it was full of screaming kids (they may have been over 18 y.o. but they acted like kids chasing each other at 3 a.m in the hall). If you ask for any info (I mean ANY) the staff at front desk look at you like you're dumb (e.g. direction to trainstation, where to buy bus tickets). I know other people who stayed there too and honestly, no one had a good word about the place and all agreed about the staff attitude and expensive price for nothing. Next time in Sydney I'll happily stay at the youth hostel and save myself the money.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: not so great This hotel is really marginal. The location is not horrible but not great either and it appears they may be a college dorm as well as a hotel - which is a bit disconcerting. The rooms were tiny and not very well cleaned.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Once bitten - twice bitten - never again! We arrived late one night expecting the average tourist hotel. Tourist - this is NOT! The front desk was mostly unhelpful and watched as my wife and I struggled through the front door with our luggage. The check-in was very brief and we were told how to get to the lifts, which require some expertise to get them going if one is unaccustomed to the keyless activation system in use. Our room was 2xsingle as that was the only smoking configuratrion available.On the way to our fourth floor room we passed some open doors many occupied by youngsters, in various stages of undress, and apparently studying. This dormitory feeling was confirmed by the signage Sydney campus apartments posted around the place.On the first and second nights I became aware that I was not alone in the bed and woke with insect bites. After reporting that to reception, something was done about the insects and I slept alone on the third night. However, we were awoken at 2:30am by a group of youngsters chatting and smoking outside our only bedroom window. Ironically that suited our required wake-up of 3:30 to catch our airport bus and thankfully leave this ghastly accommodation.The place would probably suit backpackers and students, but was definitely a mistake to stop over there on my 50th Birthday Australia tour.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: not as good as it sounds I was traveling alone on a world tour...then decided on Sydney. I stayed here for 3 nights. When I checked in, no one helped me with my 4 large bags, instead pointing me to a trolley. I pushed that trolley around the confusing maze of the hotel and up 3 flights (unairconditioned elevator). When I opened the door to my NZD$100 a night room, it smelled like cigarettes, and was very hot. The air conditioning was not on. The outside temperature was 45C, extremely hot that day! I managed to cool the room in a few hours, but was never quite sure how to run the thermostat. My view outside my window was a brick wall. The phones are hard to use, and I had to call the front desk to get me an outside line. The pool was ok, but, as with my baggage, you have to walk through a long confusing maze, using the keyless entry every so often. The gym wasnt much, and there were young boys in there chit-chatting and carrying on. The bedding was not clean and felt a little greasy, but this could be from cigarette smoke. The first morning, I asked the front desk about buses, and they pointed me to a large tourist display wall. Thanks. When I was waiting for my tour bus to arrive to take me to the Blue Mountains, no bus ever showed, and when I asked the staff about if the bus was here and left without me, they acted like I was stupid. I had to use the payphone several times to figure things out. They never offered to help me. I ended up doing something else that day. I think the bus got lost. The front door is very hard to locate, as its near a busy corner. The lobby looked great when I arrived, but was taken aback when I saw who was staying there....many many many students from foreign countries, who were unfriendly, loud, and obnoxious. I will never stay there again, nor recommend it to anyone! I felt like I couldnt leave because of the amount of bags I had, and it was the weekend. I was on a budget.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Shh! Keep it quiet at Hotel Unilodge I did not like staying at this hotel. I found it to be overpriced and it had several problems. First, the entire gym and pool facilities were not available because of a terrible smell from the restaurant next door. I complained about this but we were told that the management feels that it was ok because it was only going to be unavailable for 2 days so we deserved no apology or compensation.Second the walls were too thin. My wife heard the guy next door snoring from the bathroom (due to the sound carrying vents I assume), and then I got a phonecall from the same man asking to turn down my TV. Now my tv was not all that loud and I have never been asked to turn the sound down in a hotel before, never. I felt very uncomfortable in the room.Third, the receptionist staff were very rude and arrogant about our concerns staying at the hotel.As I said, my wife and I did not appreciate the service or facilitaties at this overpriced place.Mr BayBrisbane Australia
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: 銉︺儖銉儍銈?#x201d;   showReview(19169943, 'full');
Reviews.Author: lass=

Reviews.Content: 5娉娿仐銇俱仐銇熴亴銆侀儴灞?..   showReview(21803117, 'full');
Reviews.Author: lass=

Reviews.Content: Pratique et central   showReview(11666881, 'full');
Reviews.Author: lass=

Reviews.Content: 銇嬨仾銈婅硲銈勩亱銇с仚銆?#x201d;   showReview(19158514, 'full');
Reviews.Author: lass=

Reviews.Content: Best...   showReview(19919667, 'full');
Reviews.Author: lass=
